abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Economic Recovery
            and Governance Grant (ERGG) for Togo are to: (i) facilitate
            the clearance of Togo's arrears to International
            Development Association (IDA), which is required to restore
            normal relations between the country and the World Bank; and
            (ii) support Togo in its economic and social recovery. Given
            the complex and still fragile socio-political environment
            and governance and transparency issues facing the
            government, the second objective is pursued by supporting
            government-owned reforms to improve governance, transparency
            and efficiency in public expenditure management as well as
            advance structural reforms aimed at strengthening governance
            and transparency in the key sectors of the economy
            (phosphates, energy, cotton and financial sectors). This
            program will lead over time to strengthened fiscal
            sustainability, enhanced transparency of state institutions
            and processes, improved economic governance and increased
            economic growth. Based on current projections of debt ratios
            for end-2007, Togo will qualify for debt relief under the
            enhanced heavily indebted poor countries (HIPC) initiative.
            The operation will then pave the way for HIPC debt relief
            with attainment of the decision point expected, assuming
            continued program performance, toward the end of CY2008. The
            ERGG is expected to have a positive impact on poverty
            reduction. Specifically, efforts to improve the capacity of
            the state to implement its budget priorities and strengthen
            public financial management will enhance efficiency,
            transparency and accountability in public resource use, and
            increase the country's absorption capacity for external
            resources. Strengthening governance, transparency and
            efficiency in the phosphates sector will help improve
            government revenues and contribute to a more transparent
            utilization of resources in this sector. Strengthening
            governance and transparency in the cotton sector will
            facilitate a rebound in cotton production in the short term,
            there by improving the livelihood of an important segment of
            the population (which relies on this cash crop as dominant
            source of earnings). Improving governance and efficiency in
            the energy sector will help stimulate economic activity and
            reduce government expenditures (the savings can be used for
            increased expenditures for basic social services). Reforming
            the financial sector will help strengthen the financial
            situation of institutions affected by the crisis and improve
            the soundness of the banking sector, as well as of
            microfinance institutions which benefit the poorer and more
            vulnerable part of the population. The grant will also help
            fund the provision of basic public services with a
            beneficial impact on the poor in the period immediately
            after arrears clearance.
